editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LONDON Printed by E. A. for Thomas Archer, and are to be ſolde at his ſhop in the Popes-head-Pallace, neere the Royall Exchange. 1609.

div.head: Euerie Woman in her Humor.
div.p: GEntles of both ſexes, and all ſortes, I am ſent to bid yee welcome, I am but inſteade of a Prologue: for a ſhe prologue is as rare as an Vſurers Almes: non reperitur in vſu, and the rather I come woman, becauſe men are apt to take kindelye any kinde thing at a womans hand; and wee poore ſoules are but too kinde, if we be kindely intreated, marry otherwiſe, there I make my Apoſiopeſis: the Author hath indeede made me an honeſt merrye wench, one of his humoriſts, yet I am ſo much beholding to him, I cannot get mee a husband in his play that's worthe the hauing, vnleſſe I be better halfe of the ſutor my ſelfe: and hauing impoſed this audacity on me, he ſends me hither firſt for exerciſe I come among ye all: theſe are the Contentes, that you would heare with patience, iudge with lenity, and correct with ſmiles, for the which our endeauours ſhall ſhew it ſelfe like a tall fellow in action: if vve ſhall ioyne hands, a bargaine.
As a lowely earneſt, I giue this curteſie before, And in conceite I giue ye twenty more.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, but Accutus, prethee what miſ-ſhapen vizard of Melancholly haſt thou mask't thy ſelfe in? thou lookſt as thou wer't changing thy religion: what? is there a breach in thy Faith? come, declare, and let me ſet thy wits on worke, to amend it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Ha ha ha!

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Prettie: a man's well aduiſd to offer good counſell, and be laught at for his labour: we ſhall ſhortly haue no Counſellors but Phyſitians, I ſpend my breath to thee, and thou anſwereſt me ſome halfe an houre after in a ſembreue, or like to a Sexton with a Sobeitor Amen.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Condemne my Stars then.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I ſhould wrong am then, as thou doſt with a falſe inditement, I know it tooke not, beeing at thy birth, thou haſt bene merrie, thou haſt ſounded hoopes, ſwallowed whiffes, walkt late, worne fauours, ſeene whore ſons: thou canſt feele and vnderſtand, come, thou haſt bene a ſinner: vnloade, diſcharge, vntune, confeſſe, is venus dominatrix? art not in loue?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Yes, I loue God and my neighbors.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Then either for Gods ſake or thy Neighbors, or both, be ſmothe, and participate, iſt not ſome vnderlayer, ſome ſhe Cammell that will beare as much of her belly, as three beaſtes on their backes? ſome Lanthorne-maker, Ile holde thy head: come, vp with't.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Prethee I hate none, but heauen hate me if I be in loue with any.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Off with theſe clogs, then break priſon, and get out of this melancholly Gaole, harke how the generall noiſe doth welcome from the Parthian wars, each ſpirit's iocund, fraught with glee, then wrong not thine with this dull meditation.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Oh! how doe they then wrong my meditation? my thoughts are with themſelues at a counſell, til with noiſe and thou with continuall talke, haſt driuen them to a nonplus.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Then make me of thy counſell, and take my aduice, for ile take no denyall, Ile not leaue thee til the next new Almanackes be out of date: let him threaten the ſharpeſt weather he can, in Saint Swithin week, or it ſnow on our Ladies face, ile not budge, ile be thy mid-wife til thou beeſt deliuered of this paſſion.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Partake then, and giue me the beleefe: thinkſt thou or knowſt thou any of this opinion, that, that moouing mariſh element, that ſwels and ſwages as it pleaſe the moone, to be in bignes equall to that ſolide lump that brings vs vp?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I was ſure thou wert beyond the Antipodes: faith I am of that faith I was brought vp in, I haue heard my Father ſay, and i'me ſure his Recordes came from his Father, that the Land and Sea are in nature thus much alike; the owne growes by the Sunne, the other by the Moone, both by Gods bleſſing; and the Sea rather the greater, and ſo thinke I.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Good: there we haue a farther ſcope, and holde the ſea, can (as a looking glaſſe) anſwere with a meere ſmile any moouing ſhape vppon the earth.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, that's moſt certaine, I haue heard of Sea-horſes, Sea-calues, and Sea-monſters.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Oh, they are monſtrous madde, merrie wenches, and they are monſters Graccus, they call them Sea-maides or Mermaides ſinging ſweetelye, but none dares truſt them, and are verie like our Land-wenches, deuouring Serpents from the middle downeward.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Thou haſt euen giuen me ſatisfaction: but haſt thou this by proofe?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Not by my trauels (ſo God helpe me) marrie ile bring ye fortie Saylers will ſweare they haue ſeene them.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: In truth!

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: In truth or otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Faith they are not vnlike our land monſters, elſe why ſhould this Maximilian Lord, for whom theſe ſhoots and noyſes befits thus, forſake his honours, to ſing a Lullabye?
sp.l: Theſe ſeeming Saints, alluring euils,
That make earth Erebus, and mortals deuils.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Come, thou art Sea-ſicke, and will not be well at eaſe til thou haſt tane a vomit, vp with't.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: Why ifaith I muſt, I can not ſoothe the world
With veluet words, and oyly flatteries,
And kiſſe the ſweatie feete of magnitude,
To purchaſe ſmiles, or a deade mans office,
I cannot holde to ſee a rib of man
A moytie of it ſelfe, commaund the whole
Bafful, and bend to muliebritie
Of female ſcandals; obſerue, doe but obſerue,
Heere one walks ore-growne in weeds of pride,
The earth wants ſhape, to apply a ſimile,
A body priſoned vp with walles of wyer,
With bones of whales, ſomewhat allyed to fiſh
But from the waſt declining, more looſe doth hang,
Then her wanton dangling laſciuious locke
Thats whirld and blowne with euerie luſtfull breath.
Her necke in chaines, all naked lyes her breſt,
Her body lighter then the feathered creſt.
Another powtes and ſcoules, and hangs the lip,
Euen as the banckrout credit of her huſband,
Cannot equall her with honors liuerie,
What doth ſhe care, if for to decke her braue,
Hee's carryed from a Gate-houſe to his graue.
Another in a rayling pulppet key,
Drawes through her noſe the accent of her voice,
And in the preſence of her good man Goate,
Cries fye, now fye vppon theſe wicked men.
That vſe ſuch beaſtly and inhumane talke:
When being in priuate, all her ſtudies warne,
To make him enter into Capricorne.
Another as ſhe goes, treads a Canarie pace,
Iets it ſo fine, and minces ſo demure,
As miſtris Bride vpon her marriage day:
Her heeles are Corke, her body Atlas,
Her Beautie bought, her ſoule an Atomus.
Another with a ſpleene deuoured face,
Her eies as hollow as Anatomy:
Her tung more venome then a Serpents ſting,
Which when it wagges within her chap-faln iawes,
Is noiſe more horrid then a cry of hounds
With open mouthes, purſuing of their game,
Wants ſhe but ritch attire or coſtly dyet,
With her the Deuill can nere liue in quiet.
Yet theſe are weaker veſſels, heauen doth knowe,
Lay on them ought but eaſe, you doe them wrong:
They are as weake as water, and indeede as ſtrong,
And then like mightie ſhips, when pellets ſincke,
To them lay more men, ſheele neuer ſhrinke.

sp.speaker: Boſſ.
sp.p: Miſtris, that face wants a freſh Gloſſe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Prethee dib it in well Bos.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Pigmaleon, Pigmaleon, I coniure thee appeare,
To worke, to worke, make more Marble Ingles,
Nature, thou art a foole, Art is aboue thee:
Belzebub, paint thy face, there's ſome will loue thee.

sp.speaker: Boſ.
sp.p: Rare, Miſtris, heeres a cheeke like a Camelion or a blaſing Star: you ſhall heere me blaze it, heere's two ſaucers ſanguine in a ſable field, pomegranet, a pure pendāt, Ready to drop out of the ſtable, a pin and web argent in hayre de Roy.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: And a fooles head in the Creſt.

sp.speaker: Boſ.
sp.p: In the Creſt? oh ſweete Vermilion miſtris! tis pittie the Vermilion Wormes ſhould eate thee, ile ſet it with pretious ſtones and ye will.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Enough ſweete Boſſe, throwe a little water to ſpurt's face and lets away.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hold vp, ſo ſir now away: oh Miſtris your ſcantling, moſt ſweete miſtris moſt derydent ſtarre.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Then moſt rydent ſtarres faire fall ye.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Nay ſure tis the Moone her ſelfe, for there's her man and her Dogge before.

sp.speaker: Boſſe.
sp.p: I ſir, but the man is not in the moon, & my buſhis before me, ergo not at my backe, et ergo, not moone ſir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What's your will ſir?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: That you would leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Boſſ.
sp.p: Leaue you, zoundes ſir, we ſcorne their companies, come, they are ſtill, doe not open to them, we haue no Conies to catch.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Away, keepe no diſtance, euen both together,
For wit, ye may be Coacht together.
What ſleeke browde Saint can ſee this Idiotiſme,
The ſhape and workemanſhip of omnipotency,
To be ſo blinde with drugs of beaſtlineſſe,
And will not bend the browe, and bite the lippe,
Trouble his quiet ſoule, with venome ſpleene,
And feare leaſt the all ouer-ſeeer,
Can without vengeance, ſee theſe ignomies.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why therfore are they belooued like Sargeants, and entertained like Beggars, think'ſt thou but any honorable Gate but will be ſhut againſt theſe Butter-flies?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Oh Graecus! thou beguil'ſt opinion,
The Gates of great men ſtand more wide
To entertaine a foole, then Creſus armes,
To hug his Golden God: and faſter bard
Againſt neceſſitie, then Diues entrance
At Olympus gate.

div.stage: Enter Sernulas, Scillicet, Philantus and Boy.

sp.speaker: Sernu.
sp.p: Fa, la, ſol, laſol: Boy a Glaſſe;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Tis but one and all ſir.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Angels protect vs, what haue we heare?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ye haue a good memorie Sir, for they are fiue minutes ere windefall of your Glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, be credible, tis ballanſt to be a ſuperlatiue politicke cuſtome in theſe houres to dwell in ſhallowe accoutrements, as a defence for the abilitie of his purſſe, from the infringed Oath of ſome impudent face, that will borrowe a gentlemās reuenewes, if he be veſtally adornd: Ile tell you ſir, by this bright Horriſon—

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: A word I pray yee ſir ere ye goe any further: Boy my Tables?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your Tables are ready Sir, and all the men ye keep which is indeede halfe a Boy, Scillicet, Videlicet.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I pray ye let me requeſt that oath of you.

sp.speaker: Sern.
sp.p: A gracefull enquirie, and well obſeru'd: Sir my company ſhal make ye copious of nouelties, let your Tables befriend your memorie: write, by this bright Horriſon.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Here's none but only I, ſing: Boy, how lik'ſt thou my head of hayre?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your Glaſſe may flatter ye, but truely I will not, your head is not a hayre better then it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Is there any ſcarcitie of haire Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Somewhat thin, and yet there is more hayre then wit.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: How Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then wit of man can number ſir, take it i'th right ſence I pray yee.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Moſt ingenious!

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: O muffle, muffle good Graccûs, doe not taint thy ſence,
With ſight of theſe infectious animalles,
Leaſt reaſon in thee haue the vpper hand
To gouerne ſence, to ſee and ſhun the ſight:
Here's new diſcouered ſins, paſt all the reſt,
Men ſtriue by practiſe how to ſweare the beſt.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I haue quoted it ſir, by this bright Hore, Hore ſon, pronounce ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Seru:
sp.p: Horiſon

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Horiſon the Widowes mite Sir?

sp.speaker: Sern.
sp.p: Not for the Soldans crowne ſir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeede yee ſhall, by this bright horiſon ye ſhall, beleeue me if I ſweare, I thinke my ſelfe beholding, for I know it to be no common oath.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Were it common, it paſt not theſe doores: Sir, I ſhift my oathes as I waſh my hands, twice in the artificial day, for in dialoguiſing, tis to be obſeru'd, your ſentences muſt ironically, metaphorically, and altogether figuratiuely mixt with your morning oathes.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Faith tis verie true.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: That he neither knowes what he ſaies, nor thou vnderſtandeſt.

sp.speaker: Seru:
sp.p: As for example, by this illuminate welkin.

sp.speaker: Scel:
sp.p: Oh excellent! it ſhall downe to.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: There's another Ducket, he vtters his oathes apace.
Sure this Villaine has no ſoule, and for golde
Heele damme his body too, hee's at peace with hell,
And brings his Marchandiſe from thence to ſell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I haue heere two Miſtreſſes, but if the beſt were choſen out, if Poliphemus tother eye were out, his choice might be as good as Argus broade waking, ſo difficult is the difference.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Boy, ſleepe wayward thoughts.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Is it not now moſt amyable and faire?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes ſir God be praiſed.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: What meanſt thou Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The weather ſir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I meane my haire and face Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Twere amiable if it would not alter.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Wherfore, I often repaire it.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Me thinkes that ſhould weare it the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Not ſo Boy, for to trimme the Hayre well, is a rare qualitie: to bee rarelye quallified is to be wiſe, apply Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That you are wiſe in trimming your hayre Maiſter?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Right, to be wiſe is to be rare, for it is rare to ſee a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: True Maiſter: but if youle ſee a foole looke in your Glaſſe maiſter.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Goe to, I muſt correct you Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: You can correct no more then is your own, I am but halfe yours to commaund, if you ſteale away any parte that is not your owne, you are ſo farre in daunger as the ſtriking of an other mans ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: By this illuminate welkin moſt ſincere and ſingular, as a ſmall remembrance.

sp.speaker: Seru,
sp.p: Not for to winne the faire Angelica.

sp.speaker: Scillicet:
sp.p: By this illuminate Welkin ye ſhall now.

sp.speaker: Seru:
sp.p: Sir, I doe not beſtowe it for that I thinke you haue neede of it, for if you had, by this bright Horizon I would not giue it, for I know tis no credit to giue to the poore, by this illuminate welkin, I haue (ſince I tooke vpon me this fleſhie deſire of a Gentleman) throwne out of a window for a huntſvp, when I had as leef haue heard the grinding of a Muſtard Mill, for thoſe are thinges are heere too day and gone to morrowe: this will ſticke by a man, and doe him credit where ere hee goes.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.l: I, when the foole is clad in clay,
It will ſticke ſore vnto thy ſoule for aye.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: Signior Scillicet, I aſſure you I haue diſcouered the moſte queint and new-found deuice for the encounter of the Ladies at the enteruiew, tis in pricke-ſong.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: That's excellent and rare.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I, for prick-ſong to Ladies is moſte pleaſant and delightfull, as thus for your congie, All hayle to my belooued: then for your departure, ſad diſpaire doth driue me hence: for all muſt be to effect.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Nay, prethee raiſe no quarrels.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I can holde no longer, heare you ſir, are not you a foole? and you an Aſſe? and you a knaue?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: zoundes an Aſſe?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: A Foole?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A Knaue without reſpect?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I, for an Aſſe can beare, a Foole abide, and a Knaue deſerue:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe!

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Prethee lets away.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Fooles oftentimes brings wiſemen to trouble, Farwell, another time ile pay ye double. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Bring your Clubs out of doores, there goe in my fine hoſtes, ile talke to the proudeſt: what knaues are i'th ſtreete, my dore is my dore, my houſe is my caſtell, goe in dame Helena, let thine hoſt alon with this: he that knocks at my hobby, while I haue Ale in my houſe, ſhall pay for a Surgeon: the honeſt ſhal come in, the knaues ſhall go by: bring Clubs I ſay.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay ſir, the heare is paſt, they that did it haue tooke them to their heeles, for indeede heere are of vs—

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Away with your Clubs then, welcome my braue Bullies, my Gueſts ſhal take no wrong, but welcome my Bullies.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeede ſir I am a man of few words, I haue put vp a little blood ſhed, marrie I hope it ſhall be no ſtaine to my manhoode, if I keepe it out of my clothes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p:
He ſhall pay for the blood-ſhed, my gueſtes ſhal take no wrong: mine Hoſt will ſpend his Cruſe as franke
as an Emperor: welcome my braue bullies.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, be pacificall, the fellowe was poſſeſt with ſome critique frenzie, and wee impute it to his madnes.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Madde! by Gods ſlid if he were as madde as a weauer, I can hardly put it vp: for my blow: I care not ſo much, but he cald me foole: ſlid if I liue till I dye, the one of vs ſhall proue it.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Some prophane Villaine, ile warrant him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Doe you thinke I may not haue an action againſt him?

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: There's ſo many ſwaggerers, but alaſſe, how felye out?

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: By the welkin I gaue him not a foule word: firſt he calles me foole, then he makes a full blowe at my body, and if by good chance I had not warded it with my head, he might haue ſpoild me.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: There, there, my fine fil-pots: giue the word as you paſſe: anon anon ſir, anon: heere and there in the twinckling, looke well to the barre, there againe my little Mercuries, froath them vp to the brimme, and fill as tis needefull: if their pates be full of Wine, let your Pottles be three quarters, trip and goe, here and there: now any braue Lad waſh thy woundes with good Wine: bidde am welcom my little Sybil: put ſugar in his hole there, I muſt in to my gueſts, ſleepe ſoundly till morning: Canarie is a Iewell, and a Figge for Browne-baſtard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hoſtes.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ye are welcom, though my huſbād be a little talkatiue, yet truly he is an vnreaſonable honeſt man, yee ſhall finde his words and his ſayings all one.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: I thinke no leſſe, yet I would deſire to enter as time and place ſhall ſerue.

sp.speaker: Hoſtes:
sp.p: Ile lead the way forſooth.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p:
Nay pray ye Hoſteſſe a word, I ſay little, but i'me ſure I haue ſuſtained the moſt wrong; by this light, I
had rather he had broke my head in three places, I pray you lend me a bruſh, hee has put my hat quite out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: That ſhall ye ſir, a bruſh there hoe!

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: Salue, ſis ſaluus, I pray yee which of you fiue is the Hoſtis of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Thats eaſily diſcernd, for foure weare breeches.

sp.speaker: Bos:
sp.p: Nere the ſooner for that my diminitiue youth, for women now adaies weare breeches as well as men, mary the difference lies in the bawble.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Well ſir, to open the ttuth I am the Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: The fruit is knowne by the Tree at the firſt view, as the Author writes learnedly, come, baſilus manus.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: This kiſſing becomes a Gentleman, ile vſe it ſuret

sp.speaker: Bos:
sp.p: Secondly, Miſtris Hoſteſſe, I would knowe what lodging ye haue for my Lady and her traine.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: What will ſerue your turne ſir?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: Ile call my ſelfe to account and ſpecifie thus: my Lady and her Dogge that's two viſible: then there's the Dogge and my Lady, that's foure inuiſible: then there's my Ladies dogge and I quoth the dogge, that's ſix: then there's ſequence of three, viz. the Dogge and I and my Lady: then there's a paire of Knaues, viz the Dogge & my ſelfe, & my Lady turnd vp: viz my Lady ſequence of three: a paire of knaues, & my Lady turn'd vp to play vpon, we can haue no leſſe then fiue beds.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Truely you muſt lye cloſe together, (the Seruants I meane) for I am ſo thruſt with Gueſt I an hardly ſpare ſo many.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: Faith weele lie together as cloſe as we can: there's my Lady and her dogge lye al together, and I at the beds feete, and there's all our family of Loue.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: How farre is your miſtris behinde?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p:
The truth is, the fatall ſiſters haue cut the thred of her Corke-ſhoe, & ſhee's ſtept aſide into a Coblers ſhop to take a true ſtitch, whether I meane to ſend my ſelfe as
a Court of Guard to conduct her: but ſee, oh, inconſtant fortune! ſee where ſhee comes ſolus.

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: Bos, you ſerue me well to let me waite vpon my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Of two euils the leaſt is to be choſen, I had a care of your puppie being leſſe then your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Scil,
sp.p: Gentlewoman you haue an excellent Ch: I haue an appetite as a man would ſay.

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: What's your will ſir?

sp.speaker: Scil,
sp.p: Truth will to light, and the truth is, I haue an appetite to kiſſe you.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: This point would become a Gentleman ſure, I pray who trim'd it ſo?

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: My man forſooth.

sp.speaker: Phy,
sp.p: Sir, I deſire your acquaintance, tis excellent rare.

sp.speaker: Gent;
sp.p: You would haue ſaide ſo, had you ſeene it an houre ſince.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Heeres game for me,
I hunt for fooles, and haue ſprung a couey.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Gentles, pleaſe you draw neere? leade the way into the chambers.

sp.speaker: Bos;
sp.p: Bos is the name of a thing may be ſeene, felt, heard, or vnderſtood, and the nominatiue caſe goes before, my Miſtris the Verbe, my miſtris requires an accuſatiue caſe to follow, as vſus feminae prōptus facit. Exeunt al but Hoſtis

sp.speaker: Hoſtis;
sp.p: Oh fye vpont, who would be an hoſtis, & could do otherwiſe? Ladie, as the moſte laſciuious life, conges and kiſſes, the tyre, the hood, the rebato, the looſe bodyed Gowne, the pin in the haire, and euerie day change, when an Hoſtis muſt come and go at euerye mans pleaſure: and what's a Lady more then another body? wee haue legs and hands, rowling eyes, hanging lips, ſleek browes, & cherie cheeks, & other things as Ladies haue, but the faſhion carries it away. Prentices paſſe ouer.

sp.speaker: Hoſt;
sp.p: There, there my little Lacky boies, againe, again, my fine fil-pots, where is my fine Hoſtis? come, come my litle dido, ſet your corks on a creaking, my knaues are vnthrifty, dance not your canaries, heere, vp & down, look about to my Gueſts I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: I, I haue much ioy, an Hoſteſſe!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What, abides my Penenelope? heere ſtand thy Vliſſes, ile tarry with thee ſtil, thou ſhalt wāt for no coſt, ile buy thee a braue whiſtle, looke about to my Gueſtes I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: I, Hoſteſſes will bee knowne ſhortlye as their Signes, ſtill in one weather-beaten ſuite, as though none weare hoodes but Monkes and Ladies: and feathers, but fore-horſes, and Waiting Gentlewomen: or chaines but priſoners and Courtiers: no Perywigges but Players and Pictures, but the weakeſt muſt to the wall ſtill.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Tuſh tuſh, theſe are toies, ile none of theſe Flip-flaps, ile haue no • oping, no puffes, nor no Cobwebs: no busks nor burbarrels: thou ſhalt wear thine own haire, & fine cloath of Sheep-skins: thy colour ſhal be Dowlas, as white as a Lillie: ile kiſſe theſe chop-cheries, thou ſhalt goe Goſſip at Shroue-tide, look about to my Gueſts then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: I, twas my hard fortune to be an Hoſteſſe, time was I might haue done otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: City w:
sp.p: Why how now Woman, a'th olde diſeaſe ſtill? will it neuer be better? cannot a Woman finde one kinde man amongſt twentie? ah the daies: I haue ſeen, when a Womans will was a lawe: if I had had a minde to ſuch a thing, or ſuch a thing, I could haue had it, but twa's neuer better ſince men were Purſe-bearers.

sp.speaker: Hosty.
sp.p: Mine is eene the vnnaturalliſt man to his Wife

sp.speaker: Citie wi:
sp.p: Truely, and commonly are all ſuch fat men: ile tell thee Goſſip, I haue buried ſixe, I ſixe husbands, but if I ſhould liue to haue as many more, as I know not what may happen, but ſure ide neuer haue ſuch a fatte man: they be the moſte vnweldy men, that women ſhall not want a ſore ſtomack that's troubled with them I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: And hee maintaines me heare like I knowe not what.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: I, and what ſay, they are their wiues head, well, if he be the head, ſhee's the body, and the body is to beare the head, and the body is to beare the purſſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: They cannot miſſe vs, yet they regard vs not.

sp.speaker: Citty wife.
sp.p: Miſſe vs! no faith, but would all women were of my minde, they call vs the weaker veſſels: they ſhould finde veſſels of vs, but no weake veſſels I warrant them.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: Miſtris my Maiſter, cals for ye.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Goe, ile come anon, hee's not ſo haſtie to giue me what I want I warrant ye,

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: No, would he were, little thinkes the husband what goes through the wiues hand, waſhing, wringing and rubbing, vp earely, downe late, & a thouſand things they looke not too.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: And yet they muſt haue the gouernment of all.

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: And great reaſon they haue for it, but a wiſe man will put in a Womans hand, what? ſheele ſaue that hee ſpends.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: You haue a prettie Ruffe, how deepe is it?

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: Nay this is but ſhallowe, marrie I haue a Ruffe is a quarter deepe, meaſured by the yard.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Indeede by the yard!

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: By the ſtandard, you haue a pretty ſet too: how big is the ſteele you ſet it with?

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: As bigge as a reaſonable ſufficient—

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: Miſtris, my Maiſter would deſire you to come in.

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: What? ſhe ſhall not come yet, if you lay down the bucklers you loſe the victorie.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: By my troth I muſt goe, wee ſhall haue ſuch a coyle elſe.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: A coyle! why haue you not a tongue in your head? faith if ye win not all at that weapon, yee are not worthy to be a Woman, you heare not the news abroade:

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: No, what newes?

sp.speaker: Citty wife.
sp.p: No, I warrant ye, you neuer come abroad, this is to be troubled with a fatte man, he neuer comes abroad himſelfe, nor ſuffers his wife out of his ſight: yee ſhal euer haue a fatte Hoſt, either on his bēch at the dore, or in his chair in the chimney, & there he ſpits & ſpaules a roome like twentie Tobacco takers, oh fye on them beaſts.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: But I prethee what newes?

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: Oh woman! the moſte hard fauourd newes, and without al conſcience, they ſay there's a ſtatute made any woman that buries her husband, is not to marrie againe of two monethes after.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: A teadious time by Lady, a month were enough.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: I halfe a month, winter nights are long, and colde, ile tell ye, I haue buried ſixe, and I thank my good fortune, I euer knewe the next ere the other was in his winding ſheete.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Miſtris, my maiſter is angrie, and the Gueſts cal for their Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Goe, I come, Goſſip when ſhall I ſee you agē?

sp.speaker: Citty wi.
sp.p: Nay, when ſhall I ſee you abroad, ſildome i'me ſure.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: I muſt needes away, God buy you Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: God buy ye, Gods ſo, I haue forgot wherefore I came: a word ere you goe, the partie yee wott on commendes him vnto ye, he that met the other party in the white felt, the yellowe ſcarfe, and the round Venetian, when the other party kiſt you, and I broake the ieſt on him: when hee ſaide, kiſſes kindeles Coales, and loue ſearches.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p:
Oh! I remember him, yes faith, hee's prettie well ſet: hee ha's the right tricke with the tongue in his
kiſſe, and hee dances reaſonably comely, but he fals heauie.

sp.speaker: Citty w.
sp.p: He ſauours of a kinde of Gallant, but not of a Courtyer.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Well, weele haue a night ont, god be with ye Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: God buy ye. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Not yours nor her owne Terentia, your's in modeſtie Flauia,
See Tulley what an actiue paſſiue loue hath plaide,
I loue, and am againe beloued, but at the ſhrine
Where I doe offer vp my Cordiall ſacrifice,
I am returnd with peremptorie ſcorne,
And where I ſtand but as a gazer,
Viewing all alike, I am purſude
With violent paſſions a ſpeaking eye
Bindes fauours, and now diſcouering lines,
Thy counſell now deere friend, for at
Thy direction ſtands my thrall or freedome.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, affection is vnlimited,
Daring all dangers, hauing nor tipe nor
figure, but beyond all arte,
Then tye not that (great Lord) to Tullies awe,
Fancy forſweares all reaſon, loue all lawe.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: How well thy power can ſhun, that which
I followe with obedience, too true yfaith,
Thou mightſt as well put out the eie of day,
Or couer ſinne from heauen, or to erect
A towre of ſand, on the vncertaine ſurge,
Or any thing that were more inficient,
Then to remooue one doting thought of mine
From her diſdaine, thy aide deere Tulley.
Be thou an Orratour for Lentulus,
My tongue ſtands tund to a harſher method,
Breath in her eares thoſe Organs of receite,
A quinteſſence diſtild of honny words,
And charme with a beguiling lullabye,
Her free conſent to thine and my requeſt.
Which done, that's done, which is my ſole delight,
Which done, that's done, that I can neuer quite.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.l: All which to me are problematique mines,
Obſcurde enigmaes, and to my ſtudies
Incognite language: yet if my powers,
Haue power to cloath my tongue in loue,
Ile be a Louer, and in loue ſo pleade,
As if that Tully loued Terentia.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Thankes ſweete Cicero, this day wee dine with olde Flamiuius,
The forward Father of my Aukeward loue.
His willing minde doth ſtriue to make the peace,
Betwixt our diſcord thoughts: his free conſent
Is giuen to Lentulus, there Tulley taketh on holde,
And when a Sunne of thy intent ſhines fayre,
On ſet loues fort, with polliticke aſſaults,
And conquer conqueſt in obtaining that,
Where victors are repulſt: but ſee,
Our talke hath ouer-tane our way, ſee olde Flaminius
Comes to welcome vs,
With him a looke, looke the bright orient verge,
At the vpriſing of Auroraes ſhine.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And my good Lord, y'are happily met.

Heartily welcome: young Tullie welcome to, yee come wel to eaſe my charge, theſe Ladies finde fault with their Guardian, I goe too ſoftly for them: old blood is ſtiffe, & young Ladies wil not beare with age: I reſigne, I reſigne to you that followe.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: If they admit vs for their Guardian,
Weele dare dangers ere we part from them.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Why well ſaide my Lords, Soldiers will not flye indeede, I haue ſeene the day I could haue crackt a tree of yew, made my bowſtring, whiſper in mine care if they twang: toſt my pike luſtilye: tis ſince the ſiedge of Parthia, bith' mas a great while, I was luſtie then, at the ſeruice was done there, yet I loue the diſcourſe: come my Lord, I chuſe your companye, leaue Tulley to the Ladies, he can tell them tales of Venus and Adonis, and that beſt pleaſeth them. Now I muſt heere of raps and blowes, and Bils and Guns, and ſwords and bucklers: I loued it once, come, our Cookes are backeward, diſcourſe will begette ſtomacks, y'are like to tarrie long for leane Cates. Exit

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Now gentle Tulley, aduocate my ſuite,
Her fore-amazing perſon makes me mute.

sp.speaker: Cicero.
sp.l: Ile beare theſe Ladies company,
If they ſhall deeme acceptance. Exit

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: With intereſt of thankes to Cicero,

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Faith I like not this ods of female, an equallitie were better: yet of both twere fitter the woman ſhould vndergoe the oddes, I had rather a ſaid three men to one woman, then two women to one man: heeres Tulley addreſt to Terentia, Terentia drawing neere to Tully: her's ſmal comfot left for Flaeuia, wel gentles, ile leaue ye to the Goddeſſe: ſo ho my Lords, take me with ye.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: Nay, ſtay good Flauia,
Youle not looſe the ſight of Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Nor you of Tulley, come if you tel, ile blab.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: But ſweete Lady, Tully is not heere.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But Cicero is, his nere friend, that's as good.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: He was Lady, till hee changed his habit, by putting on the office of an vnskilfull Seruingman, intending to garde Terentia to her fathers houſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Then Flauia muſt gard her ſelfe: wel, vſe good words, and good action, and ſtalke well before your Ladie, ſhee's kindey faith, and a litele thing will pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Terent.
sp.p: Will it pleaſe Flauia to partake?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Oh fye, twere an iniurie, I could brook my ſelf therfore, ile leaue ye, but be breefe, ſtand not on pointes, cut them all firſt, & if ye fall to kiſſing, kiſſe not to long for feare ye kiſſe the poſt. Exit

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: Goe to, youle ſtill be a wagge Flauia.
But what ſaies Tulley to Terentia?

sp.speaker: Cicero.
sp.l: Lady I muſt maintaine my former argument,
Tullie's not heere, but heere is Tullies friend,
For ere I ſpeake, I muſt intreate, you wil
Transforme poore Tulley into Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: I haue no power of Metamorphoſing,
If Tulley be not heere, you muſt conceale,
I cannot make of Tulley Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Nor can the world make Cicero ſo worthy,
Yet for an houre diſcourſe a Peſants ſhape,
Nay repreſent the perſon of a king.
Then in the perſon of great Lentulus,
I doe ſalute Sunne-bright Terentia,
Lady, vouchſafe a Saint-like ſmile on him,
From that angell forme, whoſe honord minde
Lies proſtrate lowly at Terentias feete,
Who hath put off a Golden victors honour,
And left the Parthyan ſpoyle to Lepido,
Whome many Ladies haue bedeckt with fauours,
Of rich eſteeme, oh proud! he deignd to weare them,
Yet guiftes and giuers hee did ſlight eſteeme.
For why? the purpoſe of his thoughts were bent,
To ſeeke the loue of faire Terentia.
The choce is ſuch, as choiſer cannot bee,
Euen with a nimble eye his vertues, through
His ſmile is like the Meridian Sol,
Diſcern'd a dauncing in the burbling brook:
His frowne out-dares the Auſtereſt face,
Of warre or Tyranny: to ſeaſe vpon
His ſhape might force the Virgine huntreſſe
With him for euer liue a veſtall life,
His minde is vertues ouer-matcht, yet this & more
Shall dye, if this and more want force,
To winne the loue of faire Terentia,
Then gentle Lady, giue a gentle dome,
Neuer was breſt the Landlord to a heart,
More louing, faithfull, or more loyall,
Then is the breſt of noble.

sp.speaker: Teren:
sp.p: Tullie.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And why not Tullie?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It ſtands not aptly.

sp.speaker: Tere:
sp.p: It wants a ſillible.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It doth.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Then noble Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Thats too deere.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.l: Gentle is as good,
Then ſay the beſt of gentle Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Good Lady wrong not your honour ſo,
To ſeate vnworthy Tulley with your worth,
Oh looke vpon the worth of Lentulus,
Let your faire hand be beame vnto the ballance,
And with a ſtedded peyze, lift vp that beame,
In on the ſcale, put the worth of Lentulus
His ſtate, his honors, and his reuenewes,
Againſt that heauy waite: put pouertie,
The poore and naked name of Cicero,
A partner of vnregarded Orators,
Then ſhall you ſee with what celeritie,
One title of his worth will ſoone pull vp,
Poore Tullies dignitie.

sp.speaker: Tere:
sp.l: Iuſt to the height of Terentias heart,
Where I will keepe and Character that name,
And to that name my heart ſhall adde that loue,
That ſhall wey downe the worth of Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Deare Madam.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Speake ſtill if thou wilt, but not for him,
The more thou ſpeak'ſt, the more augments my loue,
If that thou canſt adde more to infinite,
The more thou ſpeakeſt, the more decreaſeth his,
If thou canſt take away, ought from nothing,
Thinke Tulley, if Lentulus can loue me,
So much and more, Terentia doth loue thee.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.l: Oh Madam!
Tulley is poore, and poore is counted baſe.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.p: Vertue is ritch and blots a poore diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Lentulus is great, his frowne's my woe,
And of a friend he will become my foe.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As he is friend, we will intreate his loue,
As he is great, his threatnings ſhall not make me loue.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Your fathers graunt, makes Lentulus your Lord,

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: But if thereto his daughter not accord,
That graunt is cancel'd, fathers may commaund,
Life before loue, for life to true loue's paund.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: How will Flaminius brooke my pouertie?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: VVell, when Flaminius ſee's no remedie,
Lord how woman like are men, when they are woe'd?
Tully, weigh me not light, nere did immodeſt bluſh
Colour theſe cheekes, but ardent.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Silence ſweete Lady, heere comes Flauia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Fie, fie, how teadious ye are: yonders great looking for Tulley, the olde Senate has put on his ſpectacles, and Lentulus and hee are turning the leaues of a dog-hay, leaues of a worme eaten Chronicle, and they want Tullies iudgement.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: About what ſweete Lady?

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: To know what yeare it was the ſhowers of raine fell in Aprill:

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: I can reſolue it by rote Lady, twas that yeare the Cuckoo ſung in May: another token Lady, there raigned in Rome a great Tyrant that yere, and many Maides loſt their heads for vſing fleſh on Fiſh daies.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: And ſome were ſacrificed as a burnt offering to the Gods of Hoſpitallitie, were they not?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Y'are a wag Flauia, but talk and you, muſt needes haue a parting blowe.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: No matter ſo we ſtand out and cloſe not.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.p: Or part faire at the cloſe and too 't againe.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Nay, if we ſhould too 't againe Terentia would growe iealous.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Ladies, I take my leaue,
And my loue.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Take heede ye ſigh not, nor looke red at the table Tully.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Your ſhoe wrings you Lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Go to, ye are a wanton Flauia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How now Terentia, in your nine Muſes?
There's none muſt pleade in your caſe but an Orator.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I want one indeede Wench, but thou haſt two, and the gentle deſtinies may ſend thee three, nere bluſh: for ſmoke and the fire of a womans loue cannot bee hid. oh a fine tongue, dipt in Helicon, a comedian tongue is the onely perſwaſiue ornament to win a Lady, why his diſcourſe is as pleaſant—

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: As how I prethee?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And keepes as good decorum; his prologue with obedience to the skirt, a rough Sceane of ciuill Warres, with a clapping concluſion, perhappes a Iigge, if not the Tragicomicall Tale of Mars and Venus, then muſt ſhee take the Tale by the end, where hee defending Mars, & ſhe Venus, muſt fall from billing to byting, from byting to blowes, to get the ſupremacie.

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.l: A good policie to praiſe Cicero,
For feare I rob you of your Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p:
Faith a Souldier is not for thy humor, now I crie a Warrier, he fights ſtoutlye in a field bed, diſcharges his worke ſure, vnder his Curtaines would I fight, but come, our Louers melt while wee meditate; thou for thy
ſcholler, I for my fouldier: and if we cannot pleaſe them ſo, weele ſhake off this looſe habit, and turne Pages to pleaſe their humors. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Come Accutus, diſcharge your follower let's leaue rubbing a while, ſince the by as runs ſo much the wrong way: Sirra, theſe bowles which we roule and turn in our lower ſpher, are by vſe made wodden worldlings right for euery one ſtriues who ſhal lye neereſt the miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: They poſt indeed, as their nature is, in an euen way, but they are cowards, theile abide no danger, they rub at euerie mole-hil, and if they tyre in going vp a hill, they retire and come backe againe.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Well, let them alley, bet all, then to reſt, away, begone.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: S foote Graccus, heeres a couple of our old gamſters, oh for quicke conceite to beget a ieſt: here's two that either a man muſt be acquainted or quarrell with, & of two euils ile choſe the latter, I hope to make it the leſſer: if I ſhould be acquainted, the foole will haunt me: if I quarrell, I may be ſo bleſt as to be rid of a foole.

sp.speaker: Grae.
sp.p: I haue a womans wit for a ſuddaine ſtratageme.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: No by my troth, by this bright horriſon—

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: An excellent Cuckoo, hee keepes his note in Winter.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I haue no appetite at all to liue in the countrie any more: now as they ſay, I haue got a ſmacke on the Cittie, ſlid I thinke (as the prouerbe goes) I was wrapt in my mothers mocke the day I was begotten, I thanke the Goddeſſe Cupid for it, I am ſo fauourd of the Women, my hoſtes loues me execrably.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: Good reaſon, fooles make good ſport.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Seuer, ſeuer, ere wee bee diſcouered.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Sir, the reſpectiue regard of your well gouerned partes do challenge a mellifluous ſpecies of enduement,
or contumelious eſtimation.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Gentles, God ſaue ye, well ouer-taken Gallants.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Welcome by the welkin.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Tis a verie pleaſant weather.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the ayre is frugall.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Is that Gentleman of your Company?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Our company ſir, no, we are no companions for lame Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Propper man, pittie he is ſo regardles: a good legge, it ſeemes he has ſome greefe in it.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, and he be lame ile talke to him, there's ſo many luſtie knaues walkes now a daies, will not ſticke to giue a man hard words, if he be not diſpoſed to charitie: harke ye ſir, I vnderſtand ye are a propper man, and that you haue a good legge.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: And what of that Sir?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: What of that? ſlid he anſweres me like a ſturdy beggar alreadie: by the fiue elements or ſences; I aske ye for no hurt, ide beſtowe my charitie as franke as—

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Stoope and looke out, zoundes a Gentleman cannot come by a misfortune in ſeruice or ſo, but euerie foole wil ride him take that— Exit.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sirra, ſtay, ile combat thee in his defence.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Sir, be pacificall, the impotent muſt bee lightly regarded.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Giue mee leaue Gentlemen, ile follow him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you be malcōtented, I haue no great hurt: but in reuenge hee's a raſcall for vſing mee ſo, hee may thank God, diſcretion gouerned me, tis wel known I haue alwaies bene a man of peace, ile not ſtrike yee the leaſt mouſe in anger, nor hurt the pooreſt Conney that goes in the ſtreet, for I know of fighting comes quarrelling, of quarrelling comes brawling, and of brawling growes hard words, and as the learned puerelis writes, tis good ſleeping in a whole skin.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, your diſcretion ſhall gouerne me at this time, your name I pray ye ſir?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: My name is ſignior Scillicet.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Euen ſo ſir? nay ſir, I doe not forget your Argument.

sp.speaker: Acut;
sp.p: Saue ye ſir, ſaw you not a Gentleman come this way euen now, ſomewhat hurt in the one of his Legges?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: He went by euen now ſir, is he a friend of yours?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: A deare friend, and a propper Gentleman ſir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the horiſon hee's a propper man indeede, he gaue me the time of the day, as hee went by: I haue a gallon of wine for him at any time, If ye ſee any thing in me worth commendations, I pray ye commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I will ſir, twere beſt you gaue me good words, but ile trie ye farther yet, fare ye well ſir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I pray you remember me to him, you ſee my anger is ouer already.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, I did not note ye, what fellow was that?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Sir, hee's a friend of his, that ſtrooke mee euen now.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Would ye not ſtrike him? lets followe.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeede ye ſhall not, I hate it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will not be barren of my armorie, in my future perambulation for the lower element.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: You are to patient in wrongs ſir, Zoundes I know not how to picke a quarrell.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Sir, the grieuous youth is inwardlye poſſeſt with a ſupple ſpirit, hee can brooke impugnying, but tis aduerſe to my ſpirit if I were armed.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Saue ye gallants, ſawe ye not a fellowe come halting this way of late?

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Hath he done any hurt, or is hee a friend of yours?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Hee's a Raſcall, and ile maintaine him ſo.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Hee's a verie Raſcall indeede, and hee vſed mee like a knaue: if ere I meete him I ſhall hardly put it vp, I haue it in blacke and blew to ſhew heere.

sp.speaker: Serr,
sp.p: Say I breath defyance to his front.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Challenge him the field.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Dooſt thinke heele anſwere me? ile challenge him at the pich-forke, or the Flaile, or ile wraſtle a fall with him for a bloody noſe, anye weapon I haue bene brought vp in, ile—

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: What will ye? heere he is, you minime that will be friend with friends, and foe with foes, and you that will defie Hercules, and out-braue Mars, and feares not the Deuill, paſſe bladder, ile make ye ſwell.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: By Gods-lid if I had knowne it had bene you, I would not haue ſaide ſo to your face. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: Away with your Champion, goe.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: This was excellentlye performd, ifaith a better breathing then a game at bowles.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Theile giue you the good ſalue any time this month, for I am ſure they haue ſaluing enough for ſo long.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: I pittie the foole yfaith, but the tother Horſeleach, I wiſh his blowes trebled: I conuerſt with him, but a Rogue ſo ſtuft with a lybrary of new minited words, ſo tearing the ſence, I neuer met with.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: But now we haue ſpoilde our determinate dinner at my hoſteſſe of the Hobbye, we ſhall nowe bee knowne.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: That holds well ſtill, I am taken for a prooued friend, and thou ſhalt be diſguiſed till I haue wrought a league by vertue of a pottle of Canarie.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Content, mine Hoſt ſhall be acceſſarie, and ile be a ſeruiter to obſerue myracles.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: They are good ſubiects for idle houres: but ſoft what ſecond courſe is entring heere?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: For I did but kiſſe her: Bos, how lik'ſt thou my reliſh?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Oh Sir, reliſh but your licour as you doe your ſong, you may goe drunke to bed any day in the weeke.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Siſter awake, cloſe not, &c. does my face hold colour ſtill?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: I, and you would but ſcauiage the pauilion of your noſe.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I marrie Accutus how likſt thou this Gentlewoman Gallant?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: A good ſtateſ man, for common wealth of Browniſts, the Rogue hates a Church like a Counter?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I, and if my Ladie Argentile were dead, he wold rather liue vppon almes then fall to worke,

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: So: he might haue tolleration,
What, ſhal's cloſe with them?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: In any caſe, but in ſome milde imbrace, for if we ſhould continue thus rough, we ſhould be ſhund like an Appoplex.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Gallants, the fortune of the day runs with ye, what all at 〈◊〉 chance? how iſt? how iſt?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sir, I think twas you beſtowd ſome abuſe of me tother day.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: Which I would wipe out of your memorie with ſatisfaction of a double curteſie.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I accept it yfaith ſir, I am not prone to anger, I aſſiſte ye the following night knewe not my anger: your acquaintance Signior.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Fye, without ceremony; lets yoake this triplicity as we did in the daies of olde, with mirth and melody.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p:
I, ſay you ſo? then Coll her and clip her, & kiſſe
her too, &c.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: The triplicitie, heere's thoſe has ſup: at an ordinarie.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: This gallant humors.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: But the other walkes a looſe.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: The triplicitie, heere's thoſe has crackt Glaſſes, & drawne blood of a Tapſter.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: The viſitation of your hand ſir.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: The Triplicitie, will colours change?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Sir, take no offence I beſeech ye, we gaue onelye ſatisfaction for an olde iniurie, but in the degree of amitie your ſelfe ſits in the ſuperlatiue.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: Not ſo ſir, but in reſpect.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: What kinde is your Dogge of Sir?

sp.speaker: Bos:
sp.p: Verie kinde to any thing but his meate, that hee deuours with great alacritie.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Where was he bred?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: In a Bitch.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: What countrie?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: A kinde of Mungrill, he will carrie, but not fetch, marrie hee is to be put to a dauncing ſchoole for inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: The tricke of the rope were excellent in him, & that ile teach him if I miſſe not my mark: come Gallants, we waſte time, the firſt Tauerne wee ariue at, weele ſee the race of an houre-glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Can ye a part in a Song?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Verie tollerably.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Weele haue a catch then, if with ſol, ſol, la: Gentlemen, haue you any good herbe? you haue match boy,

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Your pipe ſhall want no fire ſir.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Oh without ceremony: now Graccus, if we can but pawne their ſences in Sacke and Sugar, let mee alone to purſue the ſequell.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Follow it, away. Exeunt.

stage.hi: Enter Hoſtis, Cittizens wife, Scruulus and Scillicet.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: Come, come, bring them out of the ayre: alas good hearts, what rogorous villaine would commit with him? ile tell ye Goſip, hee's eene as kinde an animall, he would not wrong them yfaith.

sp.speaker: Citty wife.
sp.p: Tuſh, feare nothing woman, I hope to make him ſo againe: alacke, alacke, how fell you out, all at head? oh Butcher! are ye hurt in another place?

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: Did he not throw you againſt the ſtones?
If he did, doe not conceale, I dare ſay you gaue them not a foule word.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the illuminate welkin not a word till my mouth was full of blood, and ſo made my words foule.

sp.speaker: Citty wife.
sp.p: Is not this Gentleman hurt to?

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Onelye the extrauagant Artire of my arme is bruſed.

sp.speaker: Cittie wi:
sp.p: See, ſee, the extrauagant of his arme is bruſed to, alas how could ye quarrell ſo?

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: I will demonſtrate, in defence of the generous youth, I did appugne, my aduerſe let violently flie.

sp.speaker: Citty wife:
sp.p: Ah good hearts! would I had ſtood betwen you when he let flie ſo violently.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: We voide of hoſtile armes.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: I, if they had had horſes, they had ſau'd their armes.

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Be capable, I meane, voide of armorie.

sp.speaker: Citty wife:
sp.p: Vntill ye had had armor on.

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Had I bene accompained with my Toledo, or morglay—

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: I, your Dogge or Bitch:

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Continue I beſeech, I meane my ſword, ſole lye my ſword:

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Or ſolely your ſword, better a bad toole then none at all.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: In the concourſe.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: Nay, the concourſe will light on him for it I warrant.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: I, for the tuition of my Capitall, did mount my Semiſphere three degrees, that as a ſtrong & ſtony guard did defend my Capitall.

sp.speaker: Citty wi.
sp.p: Twas well yee kept him out, for if hee had entred on your ſtony Guard, he wold haue ſpoilde your Capitall.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: In fine being mortally aſſaild, he did preambulate or walke off.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Yes faith, he did preambulate, and walke mee finely.

sp.speaker: Cittie w
sp.p: Good heartes, how many were there of them?

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: About the number of ſeauen.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I there was ſeauen.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Or eight.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Or eight.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Rather more.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: I more at leaſt I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: A laſſe ye cannot chuſe but be more hurt, but ile ſearch you throughly be aſſured.

sp.speaker: Citty w:
sp.p: And if ſhe cannot helpe ye, fewe can, ſhee knowes what belongs to a Tent or a bruſe, and experience is good in thoſe caſes.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: I haue a concupiſcent forme of truſt in your skil, it will malladiſe.

sp.speaker: Citty wi.
sp.p: I feare not, put both your concupiſences in me for that matter.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: The generous will diſburſe coynage for ſatisfaction of your metaphiſicall endeuour.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will diſcharge all.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Wee make no doubt of that, come into a chamber, ye ſhall lye downe a while, perhaps youle bee ſtiffe anon, then you ſhall vſe your legges, the more you ſtriue with it, the better, alas good hearts. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sol, ſol, la, Tapſter, giue attendance Gentlemen, I hope all we are friends, the welkin is skie colour ſtill, and men muſt growe by degrees, you muſt pardon me, I muſt ſp—ſpeake my minde.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: The vttermoſt of your minde at this time cannot be offenſiue.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: The fryer was in the ſol, ſol, draw the tother quart, I hope you are not angrie gallants? and yee come to my lodging, ye ſhall be welcome, my Hoſtes ſhall bid you welcome: ſhee's a good wench, if I ſay the word, ſhe wil fa—full fill it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Sirra drawer, for the other thats a ſleepe, let him ſo remaine: for the Dog let him be bound to a poſt for his appearance, till I take order for his vndooing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The foole and the Dogge ſhall both take reſt at your commaund Sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I hope we are all friends, ſol, ſol, ſhals haue a catch?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: I, come come, euerie one catch a part. Sing

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Hey good boies ifaith, now a three mans ſong, or the olde downe a downe: well, things muſt be as they may, fils the other quart, muskadine with an egge is fine, theres a time for all things, bonos nocthus. Sleepe

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Good night to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: So, now Graccus ſee, what a polluted lumpe,
A deformed Chaos of vnſteddy earth
Man is, being in this ill kinde vnmād, ſeeming ſomthing
Beſtiall man, brutiſh animall: well tis thus decreede
He ſhall be what he ſeemes, that's deade.
For what in him ſhowes life, but a breathing ayre,
Which by a free conſtraint it ſelfe ingenders
In things without life: as twixt a paire of bellowes
We feele a forcible aire, hauing of it ſelfe
Force & being, no more is this breathing block,
But for his vſe in kinde: giue out in ſome burſſe or cōgregation
Among the multitude, Philantus death.
Let all the cuſtomarie rights of funerall,
His knell or what elſe be ſolemnly obſerued,
Ile take order for his winding ſheete:
And further, to furniſh it with further ſuertie,
Ile haue a potion, that for twentie houres,
Shall quench the motion of his breath.
Goe, ſpread, let me alone to effect it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Ile ſow it I warrant thee, thou talkſt of burſſe, I haue away worth ten on't, ile firſt giue it out in my Barbers ſhop, then at my ordinarie, and that's as good as a broad: and as I croſſe Tiber, my waterman ſhall attach it, heele ſend it away with the tide, then let it come out to an Oyſter wenches eare, and ſheele crie it vp and downe the ſtreetes.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Let's firſt ſecure him from eyes, and at night he ſhall be portered to our chamber: ſo, now away.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Oh a couple that would ſpred earely, let's giue it for loues ſake.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Call, call,

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Cittiy wife.
sp.p: A pox on your hemmings, doe you think we care for your hemmings,

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: Tis ſome ſtinking troubleſome knaue I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Citty wife:
sp.p: Hang him, regard him not, theres hemming indeede like a Cat, (God bleſſe vs) with a burre in her throate. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: S'hart, how we are ript vp for this?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
Oh man, this hemming is the moſt hatefulſt thing, there's not the moſte publique punck, nor worme-eaten bawd that can abide it, and honeſtie would runne madde to heare it, but come, wee waſt, time, tis now about the mid of day, we muſt ſowe arethmatike by the houres, that let the morrowes height Philantus awake againe, at which time hee ſhall bee on his Hearſe, and all the Gueſtes of the Hobbye inuited
to accompany his ghoſt, when being awake himſelfe, and all ſhall ſee, if drunkenneſſe be not mad miſterie.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But I prethee practiſe ſome milder behauiour at the ordinarie, be not al madman.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Puſh, ile bee all obſeruatiue, and yet ifaith I grieue to ſee this double garded age, all ſide coate, all foole, fye, thou keepeſt the ſports from the marke, away, and retunre what newes is now in progreſſe.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: I haue the neweſt, Terentia Daughter to the olde Senate, thogh Lentulus left the field to come to her, yet ſhe hath forſaken him in the open field, and ſhee's for our young Oratour Tully, ſhe has vowd by Venus legge, and the little God of Loue, he ſhal be her captaine, ſheele ſerue vnder him till death vs depart, and thereto I plight thee my troth.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: More Ladies Terentias, I crie ſtill,
That priſe a Saint before a Silken foole,
She that loues true learning and pompe diſdaines,
Treades on Tartarus, and Olimpus gaines.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I marrie, but then would learning be in colours proud, proud, then would not foure nobles purchaſe a benefice, two Sermons in a yeare.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: I Graccus, now thou hitſt the finger right,
Vpon the ſhoulder of Ingratitude:
Thou haſt clapt an action of flat felony
Now ill be tide that partiall iudgement,
That doomes a farmers rich, adultus,
to the ſupremacy of a Deanrie.
When needie, yet true grounded Diſcipline,
Is gouern'd with a threed bare Vycarage.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I, thou ſpeak'ſt well of their ſides that are liberally ouerſeene in the ſciences, I take no hold on't, but were all men of thy minde, then would euerie Schoolemaiſter bee a Senate, and there would neuer come Cobler to be Conſtable againe.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Ynough, ynough Graccus, let ſilence ſeale vp
Our ſecret thoughts, and libertie ſay,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Goe to I ſay, vrge no more, tis Tauerne talk, for Tauerners Table talke for all, the vomit of rumor: what newes ſaies one? none ſo new as this, Tully ſhall be married to Terentia: what newes ſaies another? the ſame, the ſame, whoſe conſent haue ye? not mine, I deny it, I muſt knowe of it, ile haue a hand, goe to, no more.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Gentle ſir,
Lay not that leaden loade of foule reproach,
Vpon ſo weake a prop, what's done is paſt recall,
If ought is done, vnfitting to be done,
The worſt is done, my life muſt anſwere it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I, you ſhall anſwere it in the Senate houſe, the Emperor ſhall knowe it: if ſhe be my childe, I will rule her, ile bridle her: ile curbe her: ile raine her, if ſhe will not, let her goe, ſtarue, begge. hang, drawe, ſinck, ſwimme ſhe gets not a do it, a deneire, ile not owne her.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Reuerend Sir be more patient.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I am impatient: I am troubled: I am vext: I am ſcoft: I am pointed at: ile not endure it: ile not abide it: ile be reuenged, I wil: of her: of you both: proud boy: wanton giglot, a ſpyring hautie, knowe your equals, ſhee's not for ye, if ye perſiſt, by my holy maker you ſhall anſwere it, looke to it, you ſhall, you ſhall indeede.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.l: I ſhall, I muſt, I will, I will indeede,
Euen to the greateſt I will anſwere it:
If great mens eares be ope to innocency,
If greatneſſe be not partiall with greatneſſe,
Euen to the greateſt I will anſwere it,
Perhaps ſome ſhallowe cenſurer will ſay,
The Orator was proud, he would climbe too hie,
But heauen and truth will ſay the contrarie.
My greateſt griefe is, I haue my friend betraide,
The treaſon's done, I, and the Traitor's free,
Yet innocent Treaſon needes not to flee,
His loyaltie bids me abide his frowne,
And he hath power to raiſe, or hurle me downe.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.l: What ailes my Tully, wherefore look'ſt thou ſad?
What diſcontent hath ſtopt the crimſon current
Which ran ſo cheerefully within that brow,
And makes it ſullen like a ſtanding poole?
Tell me, who iſt hath wrong my Cicero?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Oh wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.l: Who is it then that wrongs my Tully ſo?
What hath Terentia ought offended thee?
Dooſt thou recall thy former promiſes?
Doſt thou repent thee of—

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Oh wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.l: What hath my Father done this iniurie?
There, there, thy thoughts accord to ſay tis ſo,
I will deny him then, hee's not my father,
Hee's not my friend will enuie Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Wrong not thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: What heauie ſtring dooſt thou deuide vpon?
Wrong not him, wrong not me, wrong not thy ſelfe,
Where didſt thou learne that dolefull mandrakes note,
To kill the hearers? Tully,
Canſt thou not indure a little danger for my loue?
The fierie ſpleene of an angrie Father,
Who like a ſtorme will ſoone conſume it ſelfe,
I haue indurde a thouſand iarring houres,
Since firſt he did miſtruſt my fancies aime:
And will indure a thouſand thouſand more,
If life or diſcord either liue ſo long.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: The like will I for ſweete Terentia,
Feare not, I haue approoued armour on,
Will bide the brunt of popular reproach,
Or whatſoeuer.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Enough Tully, we are diſcouered.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Ye faith, are ye at it? what is there neuer a louing teare ſhed on neither ſide? nor you? nor you? Tullies are red, come, come ye fooles, be more breefe, I would haue buried three husbands before youle be married.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Why liues Flauia a Virgin ſtill?

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: Becauſe I haue vow'd virginitie til I can get a huſband

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Why Flauia you haue many ſuitors.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Oh I am loaden with ſuitors: for indeede I am faine to beare with any of them, I haue a dumbe ſhewe of all their pictures, each has ſent in his ſeuerall ſhadow, and I ſweare I had rather haue them then the ſubſtance of any of them.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Can you not deſcribe them in action?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes, and their action: I haue one honeſt man of the age of fortie fiue or there about, that trauerſes his ground three mile euerie morning to ſpeake to mee, and when hee is come; after the ſaluting ceremony of how do you Lady, hee falles to calculating the natiuitie of the Moone, prognoſticating what faire weather will follow, if it either ſnow or raine, ſometime with a gentle pinche by the fingar, intermixed with the valley of ſighes: hee falles to diſcourſing of the priſe of peaſe, and that is as pleaſing to me as a ſtinking breath.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: A good deſcription.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Another bringes Letters of commendation from the Conſtable of the Pariſh, or the Churchwarden, of his good behauiour and bringing vp, how hee could write and reade written hand: further, deſiring that his Father would requeſt my Father that his Fathers Sonne might marrie my Fathers Daughter, and heele make her a ioynter of a hundred pound a yeare, and beget three or foure fooles to boote.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Faemina ludificantur viros, well, forward,

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: I haue another, that I priſe derer then the reſt, amoſt ſweete youth, and if the winde ſtand with him I can ſmell him halfe a mile ere hee come at me, indeede hee weares a Musk-cat, what call ye it about him?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: What doe you call it?

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: What ye will, but hee ſmels better then burnt Roſemarie, as well as a perfuming pan, and euerie night after his firſt ſleepe, writes loueſicke ſonnets, rayling againſt left handed fortune his foe, that ſuffers his ſweete heart to frowne on him ſo.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Then it ſeemes you graunt him no fauour.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Faith I dare not venture on him for feare hee ſhould be rotten: giue me nature, not arte.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Here comes Lord Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Swift danger now ride poaſte through this paſſage, health to your honour.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And happines to you.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Tis heauen deere Lord, but—

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Tuſh, tuſh, on earth, come, come, I know your ſuite, tis graunted ſure what ere it be.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: My ſute craues death for treaſon to my friend.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.l: The Traitor liues while I haue breath to ſpend,
Then let me die to ſatisfie your will.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Neither yfaith, kneele not, riſe, riſe, I pray
You both confeſſe you haue offended me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We doe, we haue.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Then for this offence, be this your doome,
Tulley muſt die, but not till fates decree
To cut your vitall threed, or Terentia
Finde in her heart to be your Deatheſ-man?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Faith the Fates may doe as they may, but Terentia will neuer finde in her heart to kill him, ſheele firſt burie him quick.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: The like is doomde to faire Terentai,
How ſay you both, are yee content?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: My thoughts are plung'd in admiration.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: But can your honour burie ſuch a wrong?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: I can, I can, heere Tully, take Terentia,
Liue many happie yeares in faithfull loue,
This is no more then friendſhips lawes allow,
Thinke me thy ſelfe another Cicero.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Twere better my Lord, you did perſwade her to think you another Cicero, ſo you might claim ſome intereſt in her now and then.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: That I would claime with you, faire Ladie, hark in your eare, nay, I muſt conclude with you.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Y'oule not bite my Lord?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No, of my faith my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.l: Thus far my loue, our hopes haue good ſucceſſe,
One ſtorme more paſt, my griefes were much the leſſe.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Friendſhip it ſelfe hath beene more prodigal,
Then a bolde face could begge vpon a friend.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Why then, theres a bargaine.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Strike hands vpon the ſame, I am yours to commaund.
Ile loue with ye, ile lie with ye, ile loue with all my heart,
With all my ſtrength, with all my power and vertue:
Seald and deliuered in the preſence of vs:

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Marcus, Tullius, and Cicero.
Then you deliuer this as your act and deede?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: I doe, and ſeale it with this—

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Why well ſaid, tis done, ſee, we begin but now,
And are as ready to goe to Church as you:
What needes further ceremony?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes, a little matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: I Lady, come Tully and Terentia,
One day ſhall ſhine on both our Nuptialls,
Feare not, ile quench the fire of your Fathers heate
With my conſent.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: I prethee appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: About a weeke hence loue.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Oh, tis too intollerable long.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Then foure daies.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Foure daies is foure times foure & twenty hours that's too long too.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: We cannot ſooner be readie:

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes and vnreadie too, in a day and a halfe.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Well then two daies.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Til then weele feede on conceite, Tully thanke me but for your companye, I would not tarrie ſo long: come Tully ſince wee ſhall bee married all at one time, weele goe to bed ſo, and he ſhall be maiſter of the Cockpit, that bids his Goſſips firſt. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Nay quicke Graccus, leaſt our houre fore-ſtall vs, ile in and deale for your diſguiſe, tarrie thou, & giue mine hoſt a ſhare of our intent, marry charge him to keep it as ſecret as his Garbage. Hee vndoes our drift and cloathes the foole in ſack-cloath during his life.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Ile warrant thee ile manage it with as good iudgement as a Conſtable his charge.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: And I mine as a watchman his office.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Better I hope: well about it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: There, there, my little lackey boyes, giue the word as ye paſſe, look about to my gueſts there, ſcore vp at the Bar there; again, agen my fine Mercuries; if youle liue in the facultie, be rulde by inſtructions: you muſt bee eyed like a Serieant, an eare like a Belfounder, your conſcience a Schoolemaiſter, a knee like a Courtier: a foole like a Lackey, and a tongue like a Lawyere, away, away, my braue bullies: welcome ſweete Signior, I cannot bow to thy knee. I'me as ſtout & as ſtiff as a new made knight, but if I ſay the word mine Hoſt bids the Cobler—

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: May I craue a word of you mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt, whiſper in mine eare, I will ſee and ſay little, what I ſay, dūs the mouſe & welcom my bullies.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the torrid zone (ſweet heart) I haue thought well of you euer ſince I loued ye, as a man wold ſay (like a young dauncer out of all meaſure) if it pleaſe you yfaith, any thing I haue promiſed you, ile performe it to a haire, ere to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I wounder I can heare no newes of my man and my puppie.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Doe you thinke ſweet heart, to be maried by day light or by torch-light.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: By night is more Lady-like, ile haue a cryer to crie my puppie ſure.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: What thinke ye if we had an offering?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That were moſt baſe yfaith.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Baſe, ſlid I cannot tel, if it were as baſe as a ſag but ile be ſworne tis as common as a whore, tis euen as common to ſee a Baſon at the Church doore as a box at a Playhouſe.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: It greeues me not ſo much for my man, as for my puppie, my man can ſhift for himſelfe, but my poor puppie, truely I thinke I muſt take Phiſicke euen for feare ſweete heart.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Tut, tut, I warrant thee, ile be as cloſe as a bawd, ile keepe mine owne counſell, be merrie and cloſe, merrie hart liues long, let my gueſts take no wrong, & welcome my bullie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Theres none ment beleeue it ſir.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Signior, by the welk in well met, what, all three ſo luckely?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Gallants, ſauing the Ceremonie,
Stroke your haire vp and admire, for ſweare ſacke.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Forſweare Sacke, ſlid not for the ſpending of two farmes more, if they were come into my hands once,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I ſay be aſtoniſht, and forſweare ſacke, for by the cumbuſtion influence of ſacke fiue men lye breathleſſe, ready to be folded in the terreſtiall element.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Fiue ſlaine with Sacke, iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Theſe eyes are teſtators.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay then tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Getica:
sp.p: Sir, you haue not heard of a puppie in your trauels.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: No, indeed, Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Fiue beleeue me Sir.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.l: Fiue of one, oh deuil! what limme of him but a complete Villaine,
A tongue prophaner then Idolatrie:
His eye a Beacon, fixed in his place:
Diſcouering illes, but hood winckt vnto grace,
Her heart a neſt of vice, kept by the Deuill,
His good is none at all, his all, is euill,

sp.speaker: Hoſtis;
sp.p: Oh the father, Gallants, yonders the moſt hard fauourd newes walkes the ſtreetes, ſeauen men goeing to their graues that dyed with drinking and biſſeling.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Good ſtill, nay, then I ſee the deuill has ſome power ouer a woman more then a man, ſeauen! t'wll bee more anon.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Now I beſeech Bacchus my puppie has not ouer ſeene himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: This is verie ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: And as true a report I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Out al as, where's my Goſip? oh woman! haue you not heard the newes?

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Yes, I haue heard on't.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Oh woman, did your childes childe euer ſee the like, nine men to bee buried too day, that drunke healthes laſt night.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p:
Better and better, goodnes neuer mends ſo faſt
in the carrying: nine!

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: They ſay one is your gueſt Philantus,

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: And all I dare ſweare, whome ile reuiue againe

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: Well, he was a propper man yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: I, and had good skill in prick-ſong, yet hee had a fault in his humor, as none are without (but Puritans:) he would ſweare like an Elephant, and ſtampe and ſtare (God bleſſe vs) like a play-houſe book-keeper, when the actors miſſe their entrance.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay harke ye ſir, I can brooke much iniurie, but not that, meddle with me, but not with my trade, ſhee is mine owne, ſhee's meus, tuus, ſuus, no mans elſe, I aſſure ye we are ſure together.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sure ye are together ſir, but is your wife, your trade? you meane to liue vpon your wife then.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: The foole has ſome wit though his money bee gone.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, I hope ye are not offended, I aſſure ye would be loath to offend the leaſt haire of your caput, ſiſſiput, or occiput.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Occiput: what meane you by occiput?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: The former part of your head.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: The former part of your head, why I hope I haue not an occiput, in the former part of my head, Signior Sernulus, what meanes be by it?

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: The ſignification of the word onely a mounts to this, the former part of your head.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: The foole is iealious, prethee feede it.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: S'lid I cannot be ſo ſuſsified, I pray you Signior what meanes he by occuput?

sp.speaker: Grac:
