sp.p: No hurt veriely, onely, the word ſignifies, and the reaſon is (ſaith Varro) being a great deriuer from originals it is called occiput, for that the former part of the head looks likeſt the Oxe.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Likeſt the Oxe, by gad, if ere I come to talke with that Ʋarro, ile make him ſhow a better reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But howſoeuer, it proceeded from me all in kindenes.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Sir, I accept it ſo, for I tell ye I am of a mollifying nature, I can ſtrut, and againe in kindneſſe, I can ſuffer a man to breake my head, and put it vp without anger.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: I claime that priuiledge ſir, I thinke I offended you once that way.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I loue ye then for it ſir, yet I cannot remember that euer a Tapſter broke my head, yet I call to minde I haue broke many Tapſters heads.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Not as a Tapſter, for I but borrow this habyt.

sp.speaker: Scil
sp.p: The fruite is knowne by the tree, by gad I knewe by your aporn ye were a gentleman, but ſpeciallye by your flat cap.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: I call to memorie, let vs vnite with kinde imbrace.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Now well fare your harts, by my truth tis ioy to a woman, to ſee men kinde, faith you courtiers are mad fellowes, you care not in your humors to ſtab man or woman that ſtandes in your way, but in the end your kindenes appeares.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: You can reſolue vs ſir, we hear of great reuels to be at Court ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: At the marriage of Lentulus, and the Orator: verie true.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Might not a company of Wiues be beholding to thee for places that would be there without their husbands knowledge if neede were?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: A moitie of friendſhip that, ile place ye where ye ſhall ſit and ſee all.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Sit, nay if there were but good ſtandinges, we care not.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p: S'foot Graccus we tarrie too long I feare, the houre wil ouer take vs, tarrie thou and inuite the Gueſts, and Ile goe ſee his courſe mounted.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: About it.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Whether goes that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: About a needefull trouble: this gentleman
Hath at the charges of his charitie,
Preparde to inter, a friend of his,
Though lately entertaind a friend of yours.
Acquaintance to you all, Philantus: and would deſire
You would with him accompany his ghoſt
To funerall, which will be preſently on his iourney.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Of his charge, dyed he not able to purchaſe a Winding ſheete?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Twere ſinne to wrong the dead, you ſhal heare the inuentorie of his pocket.

row.cell: Inprimis, A bruſh and a Combe.
Item, A caſe of Tobacco Pipes.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: What was his ſuite worth?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: His ſute was colde, becauſe not his owne, and the owner cauſed it to be reſtored as part of recompence, hauing loſt the principall.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: What, are they readie: the Corſe is on his iourney hetherwards.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Tuſh, two womens tungs giue as loud report as a campe royall of double cannons.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Tut, tut, thou art welcom, Cornutus is my neighbour, I loue him as my ſelfe, tha'ſt a ſhrowe to thy wife, gaue her tongue to much ſtring, but let mine Hoſt giue thee counſell, heele teach thee a remedie.

sp.speaker: Cornu.
sp.p: No, no, my good Hoſt, mum, mum, no words againſt my wife, ſhee's mine owne, one fleſh & one blood, I ſhall feele her hurt, her tongue is her owne, ſo are her hands, mum, mum, no words againſt your wife.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Tut, tut, thou art a foole, keepe her cloſe from the poticarie, let her taſte of no licoras, twill make her long winded: no plums, nor no parſeneps, no peares, nor no Popperins, ſheele dreame in her ſleepe then, let her liue vpon Haſels, giue her nuts for her dyet while a toothe's in her head: giue her cheeſe for diſgeſtion: twil make her ſhort winded, if that will not ſerue, ſet fire to the pan, and blow her vp with Gun-powder.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: I, I, mine Hoſt, you are well imployed to giue a man counſell againſt his wife, they are apt enough to ill I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cornu:
sp.p: Mum, mum, my ſweete wife, I know the world wel enough, I haue an eare, but I heare not: an eye, but I ſee not: whats ſpoake againſt thee, I regard not: mum, mum, I knowe the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: I, and twere more ſeemely you were at your owne houſe too, your wife cannot goe abroad but you muſt follow, husbands muſt bee fringed to their wiues Petticoates, I pray you tarrie you, ile goe home.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not ſo my ſweet wife, I am gone, I am vaniſht, mum, mum, no anger ſhall ſtirre thee, no words, I know the world well inough.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Twere better by thrice deuce-ace in a weeke euery woman could awe her husband ſo well as ſhe.

sp.speaker: Gracc.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible, sfoot well, I thought it had bene but a fable al this while, that Iole ſhold make great Hercules ſpit on his thombes, & ſpin, but now I ſee, if a man were as great as Caeſar, Iulius, or Auguſtus, or both in one, a woman may take him downe.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Goſſip, faith ile vſe a little of your counſel, but my husband is ſo fat, I feare I ſhall neuer bring him to it.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Now gentles, you that can prepare a few teares to ſhed, for now enters a ſad ſceane of ſorrowe.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Man is fleſh, and fleſh is fraile,
The ſtrongeſt man at length muſt faile,
Man is fleſh, and fleſh is graſſe,
Conſuming time as in a glaſſe.
Now is vp, and now is downe,
And is not purchaſt by a Crowne.
Now ſeede, and now we are ſowen,
Now we wither, now are mowen,
Frater noſter heere doth lye,
In panpertate he did die.
And now is gone his viam longam,
That leades vnto his requiem aeternam
But dying needie, poore and bare,
Wanting to diſcharge the Fryer,
Vnto his graue, hees like to paſſe,
Hauing neither Dirge nor Maſſe.
So ſet forward, let him goe,

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: And then to Apollo, hollo trees, hollo, Tapſter a few more cloathes to my feete.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Oh heauens!

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Gentles, keep your places, feare nothing: in the name of God what art thou?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: My Hearſe and winding ſheete: what meanes this? why Gentles I am a liuing man.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Spirit thou ly'ſt, thou deludeſt vs.

sp.speaker: Citty wife:
sp.p: Coniure him Fryer.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: In nomino Domini, I thee charge,
Reſponde mihi heere at large.
Cuium pecus whence thou art:
Et quam obrem, thou makeſt vs ſtart,
In ſpiritus of the gloomy night?
Qui Venis huc vs to affright
Per trinitatem I there charge thee,
Quid tu vis hic to tell to me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Why gentles, I am a liuing man Philantus, what inſtance ſhall I giue ye? heare me, I haue ſight, vnderſtā ding, I know mine hoſtes, I ſee that Gentlewoman, I can feele.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Feele this Gentlewoman! s'ild if yee were ten Ghoſts, ile not indure it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Spirit thou deludeſt vs.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Why, what ſhould I ſay? will ye hsare my voice, heres none but—

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, thats a lye, then tis a liuing ſpirit, ile haue about with him.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Oh ſir, meddle not with ſhadowes, ſpirit thou lyeſt,
I ſaw thee dead, ſo did many moe:
We know ye wandring dwellers in the dark,
Haue power to ſhape you like mortallitie,
To beguile the ſimple, & deceue their ſoules,
Thou art a Deuill.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sweet Gent, beholde I am fleſh and blood, heres my fleſh feele it.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: By my troth methinkes hee ſhould be aliue, I could finde in my heart to feele his fleſh.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Trie with your Rapier Accutus, if he bleede hee liues.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: If I bleed I die, ſweet Gentlemen draw no blood.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: How ſhall wee knowe thou art fleſh and blood then?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Take heede Accutus heele blaſt thee.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: What inſtance ſhall I giue ye? I am Phylantus, he that muſt needes confeſſe he was drunk in your companies laſt day, ſweet Gentlemen conceiue me aright.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Why true, true, that we know, and thoſe ſwilling bowels,
Death did arreſt thee, many ſaw thee deade,
Elſe needles were theſe rites of funeralls,
And ſince that time till now, no breath was knowne.
Flye from you: and twentie times the houre-glaſſe,
Hath turnd his vpſide downe: and twenty times
The nimble current ſand hath left his vpper roome,
To ly beneath, ſince ſparke of life appeard,
In all which time, my care imploide it ſelfe,
To giue the rights of buriall: now if you liue,
Who ſo glad as I?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sir, your loue hath ſhowne it ſelfe aboundant, but the colde aire is a meanes to deuorce me from your companies: mine hoſt let me craue paſſage to my chāber.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Out of my dores knaue, thou entereſt not my dores, I haue no chalke in my houſe, my poſts ſhal not be garded with a little ſing ſong, ſi nihil attuleris ibis Homere foras.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Ha, how now man? ſee'ſt now any errors?
Nay, this is no thing: he hath but ſhowne
A patterne in himſelfe, what thou ſhalt finde
In others: ſearch through the Globe of earth
If there mongſt twentie, two thou dooſt finde
Honeſter then himſelfe, ile be buried ſtraight,
Now thinke what ſhame tis to be vilde,
And how vilde to be drunk: looke round, where?
Nay looke vp, beholde you Chriſtall pallace,
There ſits an vbiquitarie Iudge,
From whome arcana nulla abſcondita.
That ſee's all and at pleaſure puniſheth,
Thou canſt not ſcape ſcot free, how canſt thou?
Why ſenceleſſe man, in that, ſinne will betray
His father, brother, nay, him himſelfe: feares not
To commit the worſt of euils: ſecure, if
Thunder boults ſhould drop from heauen, dreading
Nor heauen nor hell: indeede hss beſt ſtate
Is worſe then leaſt, priſed at higheſt rate.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This critique is hoarſh, vnſauerie, and reproofeful, avoyd him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p:
Hee ſpeakes well, but I like not his diſprayſing
of drunkennes: tis Phiſicke to me, and it makes mee to ſleep like a good horſe, with my noſe in the maunger, come ſweete heart.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Signior Philantus I pray ye a word. Exit

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: How now, whiſpering? s'foot if they ſhould giue our purpoſe another croſſe point, where are wee then? note, note.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis,
sp.p: Heere take the key, conuey your ſelfe into the Chamber, but in any caſe take heede my husband ſee you not.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Feare not: gentles, be thanks the guerden of your loue, till time giue better abilitie, Exit.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Ha! nay s'foot, I muſt claw out another deuice: we muſt not part ſo, Graccus prethee keepe the ſceane til I fetch more actors to fill it fuller.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: But prethee let me partake.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Not till I returne, pardon me, Exit

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: By my troth goſſip I am halfe ſicke of a conceit

sp.speaker: Cittiy wife.
sp.p: What woman? paſſion of my heart, tel me your greefe?

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: I ſhall goe to court now, and attired like an old Darie woman, a Ruffe, holland of eight groates, three inches-deepe of the olde cut, and a hat as farre out of faſhion as a cloſe placket.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Why I hope your husband is able to maintaine you better: are there not nights as well as daies? does he not ſleepe ſome times? has hee no pockets about him? cannot you ſearch his breeches? anye thing you finde in his breeches is your owne.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: But may a woman doe that with ſafetie?

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: I and more, why ſhould ſhee not? why what is his is yours, what's yours, your owne:

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p:
The beſt hope I haue is, you knowe my Gueſt Miſtris Gettica, ſhe has pawnd her Iewels to me already, and this night I look for her Hood, and her tyer, or if the worſt chance, I knowe I can intreate her to weare my
cloathes, and let me goe in her attire to Court.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Or if all faile, you may hire a good ſuite at a Iewes: or at a broakers, tis a common thing and ſpecially among the common ſort.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: To ſearch through my houſe, I haue no Varlets no knaues, no ſtewd prunes, no ſhe fierie phagies, my Chambers are ſwept, my ſinkes are all ſcowred, the honeſt ſhal come in, the knaues ſhall go by, yet wil I maiſter Conſtable, goe ſearch through my houſe, I care not a ſheepes skin.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: We are compeld to doe it mine hoſt, a Gentlemā is robd laſt night, & we are to ſearch euery priuy corner.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Mine hoſt is true Mettall, a man of reputation, a true Holefernes, he loues iuice of grapes, and welcom maiſter Conſtable. Exit

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Graccus, how likſt thou this?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Excellent, for now muſt he needes fall into the Conſtables hands: and if he haue any grace, twil appear in his face, when he ſhall be carried through the ſtreete in a white ſheet twill be a good penance for his fault.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Now fortune fauour that my husband find him not

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Heele be horne mad, & neuer able to indure it: why woman if he haue but as much man in him as a Maribone, heele take the burthen vppon his own necke, and neuer diſcouer you

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Alas heere they come, lets away Goſſip. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Fortune my foe, why dooſt, &c.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Oh fye, that's bitter, pre the goe comfort him.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Faith he ſhould be innocent by his garment: Signior, I grieue for this, but if I can help, looke for it.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I thanke ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: We muſt contaminate our office, pray regard vs as little as ye can. Exit

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
Me thinkes this ſhold put him quite out of tune: now ſo, let him goe, now to mine Hoſt, theres he, and hee,
and h • e, theres ſhee, and ſhe, ile haue about with all: & critiques, honnys ſweeteſt, mixt with gal. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Hoſt;
sp.p: Goe to, there's knaues in my houſe, I know of no Varlets, I haue an eye has his ſence, a braine that can reach, I haue bene cald Polititian, my wife is my wife, I am her top, i'me her head: if mine Hoſt ſay the word, the Mouſe ſhall be dun.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Not ſo my ſweet Hoſt, mum, mum, no words againſt your wife, he that meanes to liue quiet, to ſleep in cleane ſheetes, a Pillowe vnder his head, his dyet dreſt cteanely, mum, mum, no words againſt his wife.

sp.speaker: Hoſt,
sp.p: Thar't a foole, thar't a foole, bee rulde by mine hoſt, ſhew thy ſelf a braue man of the true ſeede of Troy; a gallant Agamemnon, tha'ſt a ſhrew to thy wife, if ſhee croſſe thy braue humors, kicke thy heele at her huckle bone.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Gentles, moſt happily encountred, how good hap hath turnd two labours into one, I was addreſt to both, and at once haue met both, ſure I muſt intreate that you muſt not deny.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Say on my ſweete bullie, mine Hoſt will attend thee, ſpeake roundly to the purpoſe and welcome my bullie.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Marrie thus: there are are great reuels & ſhews preparde to beautifie the nuptials of Lentulus and Tully, in which the Cittizens haue the leaſt ſhare, now would but you and ſome others that I ſhall collect, ioyne hands with me in ſome queint ieſt,
Our ſhew ſhall deſerue grace, and braue the reſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I haue thee braue ſpirit, tha'rt of the true ſeed of Troy, lets bee merrie and wiſe, merrie hearts liue long mine Hoſt, my braue Hoſt with his neighbor Cornutus ſhall bee two of the Maskers, and the Morrice ſhall bee daunc'd,

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.p: Not ſo mine Hoſt, I dare not doe ſo, t'wil deſtemper my wife, my houſe will be vnquiet, mum, mum, I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt goe ſaies mine Hoſt, merrie hearts liue long, welcome bully, mine Hoſt ſhall make one, ſo ſhal my Cornutus, for if I ſay the word the mouſe ſhall be dun. Enter Bos with Porters.

sp.speaker: Porters.
sp.p: Saue ye mine Hoſt, heeres a parcell of Corne was directed to be deliuered at your houſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: What ware my little Atlas, what ware is it?

sp.speaker: 2. Por:
sp.p: I know not, but i'me ſure tis as heauie as a horſe and—

sp.speaker: 1 Por:
sp.p: I thinke tis a barrel of oyle, for it ſpurg'd at my backe.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: It was oyle, for I drew the Tap.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: What Bos, what makſt thou heere?

sp.speaker: Acc:
sp.p: Oh charadeum ſoboles magnum bouis increm entum! Bos art there there?

sp.speaker: Bos:
sp.p: As ſure as you are there Signior.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Bos, will ye not forſake your Cabbin?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: Oh ſir, he that has not a tilde houſe muſt bee glad of a thatcht houſe: may I craue a ſuite of you ſignior?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: What ſuite Bos?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: What you pleaſe, beggers muſt not chuſe.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Bos is growne miſticall, hee's too dark.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: I ſpeake hebrew indeed like Adam and Eue, before they fel to ſpinning: not a rag.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: What, naked Bos?

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p: As ye ſee, will ye heare my ſuite ſignior?

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Drunk & his cloathes ſtoln, what theef wold do it?

sp.speaker: Bos:
sp.p: Any theefe ſir, but no true man.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Wel Bos, to obtaine a ſuite at my handes, and to doe ſome pennance for your fault, you ſhal here maintaine an argument in the defence of drunkennes: mine Hoſt ſhall heare it ile be your oppoment, Acutus moderator: wilt thou doe it.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: A mad merrie prig, all good ſpirits, wilt thou doe it Bos?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Ile doo't.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Seate yee, heres my place, now Bos propound.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Drunkennes is a vertue.

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Your proofe.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Good drinke is full of vertue,
Now full of good drinke is drunke,
Erge, to be drunke is to be vertuous.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: I deny it, good drinke is full of vice,
Drinke takes away the ſences,
Man that is ſenceleſſe is vitious,
Ergo, good drinke is full of vice.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.l: I deny it ſtill, good drinke makes good bloud,
Good blood needes no Barber,
Ergo, tis good to drinke good drinke.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: Hee holdes ye hard Graccus.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Heeres ſtronger proofe, drunkenneſſe ingenders with two of the morrall vertues, and ſixe of the lyberall ſciences.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Let him prooue that and Ile yeeld.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: A mad ſpirit yfaith.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: A drunkard is valiant and lyberall, heele out-face Mars, braue Hercules, and feares not the Deuill, then for the moſt part hee's liberal, for heele giue all the cloathes off his backe, though hee weepe like a Widowe all the day following: nay, for the ſciences, hee's a good phiſitian hee vomits himſelfe rarelie, and will giue any man elſe a vomit that lookes on him (if hee haue not a verie good ſtomacke) perfect in Geomitrie, for he hanges in the aire by his owne conceite, and feeles no ground: and hee's all muſicall, the world turnes round with him, euerie face in the painted cloath ſhewes like a Fairie dauncing about him, and euerie ſpar in the houſe a minſtrell.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Good: forward.

sp.speaker: Bos
sp.p:
Then hee's a good Lawyer, for hees neuer without a fierie facies, & the leaſte Capias will take his habeas Corpus: beſides, another point of a Lawyere, heele raile
and raue againſt his deareſt friends, and make the world think they are enemies, when the next day theile laugh, bee fat and drunk together: and a rare Aſtronomer, for he has ſtarres twinckling in his eyes, in the darkeſt night, when a wiſe man diſcernes none in the firmanent, and will take great paines in the practiſe: for lay him on his backe in the open fields ouernight, and you ſhall be ſure to finde him there in the morning: haue I ſed well, or ſhall I giue you a ſtronger proofe? an honeſt man will be as good as his word: Signior Graccus is an honeſt man, Ergo I muſt haue a new ſuite.

sp.speaker: Accu:
sp.p: The moderator concludes ſo, Graccus is ouerthrown ſo far as the damage of a ſuite, ſo away with him, come, our fire will out, ſtrip vs, mine Hoſt and you wee expect your companies, we muſt craue abſence a while, better to furniſhe our purpoſes: the time of the day to ye.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Farwel my good bullies, mine Hoſt has ſed & the mouſe is dun.

div.stage: Enter the dumb ſhew of the marriage, Lentulus, Tully, and the rest. Enter Hoſtis in Getticaes apparel, Getic. in hers, & Miſtris Dama.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Come Goſſip, by my troth I cannot keepe my hood in frame.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Let me helpe ye woman.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Sir, we ſhall be troubleſome to ye.

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Oh vrge not that I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I pray yee what ſhowe will be heere to night? I haue ſeen the Babones already, the Cittie of new Niniuie, and Iulius Caeſar acted by the Mammets.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Oh gentlewoman, thoſe are ſhowes for thoſe places they are vſed in, marry here you muſt expect ſome rare deuice as Diana bathing her ſelfe, being diſcouered or occulated, by Acteon, he was trāfigured to a hart, & werried to death with his own dogs.

sp.speaker: Cit. w.
sp.p: Thats prettie in good truth, & muſt Diana be naked?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Oh of neceſſitie, if it be that ſhow.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: And Acteon too? thats prettie ifaith.

div.stage: Enter Caeſar, Lent. Tully, Teren, Flauia.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.l: Now gallant Bridegroomes, and your louely Brides,
That haue ingeminate, in endleſſe league,
Your troth-plight hearts in your nuptial vowes,
Tyed true loue knots, that nothing can diſolue,
Till death that meager purſeuant of Ioue,
That Cancels all bonds: we are to clowdie,
My ſpirit a typtoe nothing I could chid ſo much,
As winged time that gins to free a paſſage,
To his turrent glaſſe, and crops our day-light
That miſtie night will ſummon vs to reſt,
Before we feele the burthen of our ey-lids.
The time is teadious, wants varietie,
But that I may ſhew what delightfull raptures,
Combats my ſoule, to ſee this vnion,
And with what boundles ioy I doe imbrace it,
We heere commaund all priſon gates flye ope,
Freeing all priſoners, (traitors all except,
That poore mens prayers may increaſe our daies,
And writers circle ye with wreathes of bayes.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: S'foot Accutus lets lay hold of this, to free our captiue.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p: Content; ile proſecute it.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Dreade ſoueraigne, heauen witneſſe with me,
With what bended ſpirit I haue attainde
This height of happineſſe: and how vnwillingly,
Till heauens decree, Terentias loue, and your
Faire conſents, did meet in one, to make
Me Lord thereof: nor ſhall it adde one ſcruple,
Of high thought to my lowly minde.
Tully is Tully, parentage poore, the beſt,
An Orator, but equall with the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Oh no doubt Accutus, be the attempt,
My perill, his royall promiſe is paſt
In that behalfe: my ſoueraigne, this Gentlemans
Requeſt, takes holde vpon your gatious promiſe,
For the releaſement of a priſoner.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: My promiſe is irreuocable, take it: but what is hee and the qualitie of his fault?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: A gentleman, may it pleaſe your grace, his fault ſuſpition, and moſt likely innocent.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.l: He hath freedome, and I prethee let him be brought hither
Perhaps in his preſence we ſhall win ſome ſmiles,
For I haue noted oft in a ſimple braine
(Only ſtriuing to excell it ſelfe)
Hath corrupted language that hath turnd
To pleaſant laughter, in iuditious eares;
Such may this prooue, for now me thinkes
Each minute, wanting ſport doth feeme
As long and teadious, as a feauer: but who doth knowe
The true condition of this Accutus?

sp.speaker: Tully:
sp.l: My Leige, of him ſomething my knowledge,
Can diſcouer, his ſpirit is free as aire,
His temper temperate, if ought's vneeuen,
His ſpleene waies downe lenitie: but how
Stird by reproofe, and then hee's bitter, and like
His name, Acute, vice to him is a foule eye-ſore.
And could he ſtifle it in bittereſt words, he would,
And who ſo offends, to him is paralell,
He will as ſoone reprooue the Caedar ſtate,
As the lowe ſhrub. Enter Acut. and Philant.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Nay good Accutus let me not enter the preſence:

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Oh ſir, I aſſure you your preſence wil be more acceptable in the preſence at this time, then a farre ritcher preſent: May it pleaſe your maieſtie, this is the man.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Let him ſtand forward.

sp.speaker: Cit. w.
sp.p: Alas we ſhal ſee nothing, would I were neere now hee ſtands forwards.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: What qualities hath he Accutus?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Few good ones (may it pleaſe you) he handles a comb wel, a bruſh better, and will drink Downe a Dutchman, & has good skill in prickſong.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: I, ile be ſworne, he had when he was my Gueſt,

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Pleaſe it your Maieſtie to commaund him?

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Oh, we can no otherwiſe ſo well be pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I beſeech your Maieſtie, I cannot ſing.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Nay, your denyall will breed but greater expectation of your skill.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I, I, pleaſe it your grace to heare? now he begins.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: My loue can ſing no other ſong, but ſtill complaines I did her. &c. I beſeech your Maieſtie to let me goe.

sp.speaker: Caeſ:
sp.p: With all our heart, Acutus giue him libertie.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Goe, and for voice ſake yee ſhall ſing Ballads in the ſuburbes, and if euer heereafter ye chance to purchaſe a ſuite by what your friends ſhal leaue ye, or the credit of your friend, be not drunk again, & giue him hard words for his labour. Exit

sp.speaker: Caeſ:
sp.p: What, iſt effected Graccus?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I haue wrought the foole, Scilicet comes alone, & his Lady keeps the women company.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: Tuſh, weele haue a room ſcantly furniſht with lights that ſhall further it.

sp.speaker: Caeſ:
sp.p: What ſound is that?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: I, would ye ſo faine enter? ile further it: pleaſe it your Maieſtie to accept what is not worth acceptance? heere are a company to Gratulate theſe nuptials, haue prepard a ſhow, I feare not worth the ſight, if you ſhall deeme to giue them the beholding of it.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Elſe ſhould we wrong their kindnes much: Accutus, be it your care to giue them kindeſt welcome, we cannot recompence their loues without much beholdings.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Now for the cunning vizarding of them, & tis done.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis:
sp.p: Now we ſhall beholde the ſhowes.

sp.speaker: Get
sp.p: Acteon and his Dogs I pray Iupiter.

stage.hi: Enter the maſke and the Song,
stage.l: Oh how they begin, harke, harke!

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Sli'd there's one bird I doe not like her voice.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: By my troth me thought one ſhould be my huſband, I could euen diſcerne his voice thorough his vizard.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: And truely by his head one ſhould be mine.

sp.speaker: Get:
sp.p: And ſurely by his eares one ſhould be my ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.l: Accutus, you haue deſerued much of our loue,
But might we not breake the law of ſport ſo farre,
As to know to whome our thankes is due,
By ſeeing them vnmaskt, and the reaſon of their habits?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Moſt willingly my Soueraigne, ile cauſe their returne.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: Oh excellent! now we ſhal ſee them vnmaskt. Exit

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: In troth I had good hope the formoſt had bene Acteon when I ſaw his hornes.

sp.speaker: Cit. wif.
sp.p: Sure the middlemoſt was my husband, ſee if he haue not a wen in his fore-head.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: God bleſſe thee noble Caeſar, & all theſe braue bridegroomes with their fine little dy-doppers, that looke before they ſleep to throw away their maiden heads: I am hoſt of the Hobbie, Cornut is my neighbour, but wele pull of his bopeeper, thou't know me by my noſe, I am a mad merie grig, come to make thy grace laugh, ſir Scillicet my gueſt, all true canaries that loue iuce of grapes, god bleſſe thy Maieſtie.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: How now mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I ſpie a ieſt, ha ha, Cornutus, Cornutus.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Nay mine hoſt, heeres a moate in your eye to.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Sl'id I hope they haue not ſeru'd me ſo: by the torrid y'are an aſſe, a flat Aſſe, but the beſt is I know who did it, t'was either you or ſome body elſe, for I was in no company of mankinde elſe, by gad I remember it as wel as if it were done now.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Tou ſhalt anſwere it to my leige, ile not be ſo miſuſed, ye haue a wrong element, there's fire in my face, weele moūt and aſcend.
sp.l: I'me miſuſd the mad comrades haue plaide the knaues,
Iuſtice my braue Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.l: Ile anſwere ye mine Hoſt: pardon greate Caeſar,
The intent was merriment, the reaſon this:
A true brow bends, to ſee good things amiſſe,
Men turnd to beaſts, and ſuch are you mine Hoſt
See you this, this repreſents a beaſt,
That cannot ſee his ſhame, & ſuch are you mine Hoſt.
Ile ſhow you elſe, you are a Goate, looke heere!
Now come you, this is your's, you know it, doe you not?
How old are you? are you not a Goate now?
Shall I teach thee how to vſe a wife and keepe her?
In the ranke of goodnes linke her to thy ſoule,
Deuide not indiuidium, be her and ſhee thee,
Keepe her from the Serpent, let her not Gad
To euerie Goſſips congregation,
For there is bluſhing modeſtie laide out,
And a free reyne to ſenſual turpitude,
Giuen out at length and lybidinous acts,
Free chat, each giuing counſell and ſenſure.
Capream maritum facere, ſuch art thou Goate,
Be not ſo ſecure: and you my graund Cornutus,
Thou Ram, thou ſeeſt thy ſhame a pent-houſe
To thy eye-browes: dooſt not glorie in it, dooſt?
Thou'lt lye in a Trucklebed, at thy wiues bed feete,
And let her goe a Goſſiping while thou ſweepeſt the ktchin,
Look, ſhe ſhall witneſſes againſt thee.

sp.speaker: Corn:
sp.p: My wife there? I muſt be gone then.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Oh fie, betray not thy ſelfe ſo groſſely.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I Pray ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.l: I ſir, but afterward may come after claps,
I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Miſchiefe of the Deuill, be man not all beaſt, doe not lye, —both ſheetes doe not.

sp.speaker: Cit. w:
sp.p: I warrant this fellow has as many eies as a Lamprey, hee could neuer ſee ſo farre into the world elſe.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: And thou pure aſſe, meere aſſe, thy eares become thee well yfaith

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I think you ment to make a Muſition of me, you furniſh me with a good eare.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Thou deſerudſt it, thou't make thy ſelfe a Cucckold be it but for company ſake, thou haſt long eares, and thinkeſt them hornes, thy conceites cuckolds thee, thou art iealious if thou ſeeſt thy wiues — With another mans palme.

And foole, thy ſtate in that ſence is the beſt: thou art claſpt with ſimplicitie, (a great badge of honeſtie) for ſhe poore foole has paund her cloathes to redeeme thy vnthriftines: be Iealious no more, vnleſſe thoult weare thine eares ſtill, for all ſhall be well and you ſhall haue your puppie againe.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Shall I? by my troth I ſhall be beholding to you then.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.l: Now to ye all, be firmaments to ſtars,
Be ſtars to Firmaments, and as you are
Splendent, ſo be fixed, not wandring, nor
Irregular, both keeping courſe together,
Shine not in pride, and gorgeous attire,
When clouds doe faile, the pole where thou art fixt.
Obey, cheriſh, honor, be kinde enough,
But let them weare no changeable ſtuffe,
Keepe them, as ſhall become your ſtate,
Comely, and to creepe ere they goe.
Let them partake your ioyes, and weep with you,
Curle not the ſnarles that dwel vpon theſe browes,
In all things be you kinde of all enough,
But let them weare no changeable ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Fore God a mad ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis
sp.p: Will ye beleeue, what ſuch a bisket brain'd fellow as this ſaies? he has a mouth like a double cannon, the report will be heard all ore the towne.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: I warrant he ranne mad for loue, becauſe no good face could endure the ſight of him, and euer ſince he railes againſt women like a whot ſhot.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Nay, nay, we muſt haue all friendes.
Iarring diſcords are no marriage muſick,
Throw not Hymen in a cuckſtoole, dimple
Your furrowed browes, ſince all but mirth was ment,
Let vs not then conclude in diſcontent.
Say, ſhall we all in friendly ſtraine
Meaſure our paces to bed-ward?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Will Terentia follow?

sp.speaker: Teren:
sp.p: If Tully be her Leader.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Good bloods, good ſpirits, let me anſwere for all, none ſpeake but mine Hoſt, hee has his pols and his aedypols, his times and his tricks, his quirkes and his quilits, and his demiſe and dementions, God bleſſe thee Noble Caeſar, and all theſe braue ſpirits, I am Hoſt of the Hobby, Cornutus is my neighbour: Graccus a mad ſpirit, Accutus is my friend, Sir Scillicet is my gueſt, al mad comrades of the true ſeed of troy, that loue iuice of Grapes: we are all true friends, merrie harts liue long, let the Pipers ſtrike vp ile daunce my cinquepace, cut a loft my braue capers, whirle about my toe, doe my tricks aboue groūd, ile kiſſe my ſweet hoſteſſe, make a curteſie to thy grace, God bleſſe thy Maieſtie, and the Mouſe ſhall be dun.

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.p: Come wife, will you dance?

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Ile not daunce I, muſt you come to the Court to haue hornes ſet on your head? I could haue done that at home.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: I, I, be rulde at this time, what, for one merrie day wele finde a whole moone at mid-ſommer.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Gentles, wee thanke yee all, the night hath ſpent his youth, and drowſie Morpheus bids vs battell,
sp.l: We will defie him ſtill, weele keepe him out
While we haue power to doe it, ſound your lowdeſt noiſe,
Set forward to our chamber.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Aduance your light.

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Good reſt to all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God giue your grace God night. Exeunt
